abn
Class ActionController

java.lang.Object
  abn.ActionController
Direct Known Subclasses:
ApplicationController
public abstract class ActionController
extends java.lang.Object

Inspired by Ruby On Rails (http://www.rubyonrails.org), this class along with ApplicationController, provides a simple way to call controller actions by just setting a name on them.

This class handles all controller actions. All controllers should extend ApplicationController, that in turn extend this class. This will result in that all controllers will handle some events the same way.

Usage

If you want to connect an event to a Component, Say for example a JButton, you add a listener as usual: 

 JButton button = new JButton("Some button");
 button.addActionListener(controller);

Note that the event should always go to the controller.

After this there's one more thing to do. And that is to give the Component a name with the setName method. 

 button.setName("action");

The name of the method that will be called in the controller, that was connected to the component, is the one with the same name as the component name. This however, is only true, if there's a method in the controller with that name, taking no arguments. So for the above example the action name method in the controller named controller will be called when button is clicked.

However. If there is no method named action in the controller. A method defined in ApplicationController called methodMissing is called. This is handy for dynamic action calling. So in your controller, you can override this method to get some other behavior.

Before the action is called, a method called beforeFilter is called. And after a method called afterFilter. Read comments in ApplicationController for more information.

Two variables are by default available in the sub-controllers.

  • event - Is the event that was fired.
  • name - Is the name of the component that the event was fired on.

Troubleshooting

If the above does not work. Start by reading the comments in ApplicationController.

If you done that and it still doesn't work, make sure that this class implements the listener class you want to use. Say for example that you want to add a ActionListener to your controller. Then this class must implement ActionListener and have all methods from that interface. In this case it's only actionPerformed.

And in the method you should first set the event instance variable to the event that is passed to the method. And then call callActionByName.
Example: 

 public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e)
 {
   this.event = e;
 
   callActionByName();
 }

One more thing to check is if your controller is created or not. Because if you send null to addActionListener, you don't get any errors.
